title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: vignette explains algorithms used paneffectR clustering proteins analyzing presence/absence data. ’s intended bioinformaticians want understand technical details.
code: library(paneffectR)

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: default clustering method (diamond_rbh) uses two-phase “seed expand” algorithm builds orthogroups spanning multiple assemblies.

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Reciprocal Best Hits (RBH) classic approach finding orthologs two genomes: protein genome 1, find best hit B genome 2 protein B genome 2, find best hit genome 1 B’s best hit , reciprocal best hits Limitation: RBH produces pairs. 10 assemblies conserved protein family, pure RBH gives 45 pairs (10 choose 2), one orthogroup 10 members.

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: paneffectR solves two-phase approach:

previous_headings: Clustering: DIAMOND RBH + Expansion > The Solution: Seed and Expand
title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Run -vs-DIAMOND blastp Identify RBH pairs across assemblies Build initial orthogroups via connected components RBH graph proteins -B RBH B-C RBH, , B, C form one orthogroup.
code: Assembly 1: [A] ──RBH──┐                        │ Assembly 2: [B] ──RBH──┼──RBH── [D] Assembly 4                        │ Assembly 3: [C] ──RBH──┘  Result: Orthogroup {A, B, C, D}

previous_headings: Clustering: DIAMOND RBH + Expansion > The Solution: Seed and Expand
title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: proteins may reciprocal best hits (due gene loss, divergence, assembly gaps) still belong orthogroup. expansion phase adds : unclustered protein (singleton), find best hit best hit already orthogroup, add singleton orthogroup Repeat proteins can added approach balances precision (RBH seeds high-confidence) recall (expansion captures divergent members).
code: Before expansion:   Orthogroup OG1: {A, B, C}   Singletons: {D, E, F}  D's best hit = B (in OG1) → Add D to OG1 E's best hit = D (now in OG1) → Add E to OG1 F's best hit = X (not in any orthogroup) → F stays singleton  After expansion:   Orthogroup OG1: {A, B, C, D, E}   Singletons: {F}

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: clustering parameters affect sensitivity specificity:
code: # Fast mode (default) clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, mode = "fast")  # More sensitive (slower, finds divergent homologs) clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, mode = "thorough")  # Stricter thresholds (fewer, more confident orthogroups) clusters <- cluster_proteins(   proteins,   min_identity = 50,   min_coverage = 70 )

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: clustering assemblies orthogroup content, choice distance metric matters.

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Simple presence/absence treated 0/1: dbinary(,B)=∑(xAi−xBi)2d_{binary}(, B) = \sqrt{\sum_i (x_{Ai} - x_{Bi})^2} xAix_{Ai} 1 orthogroup ii present assembly AA, else 0. Characteristics: - Sensitive total number differences - single shared orthogroup 100 shared orthogroups contribute differently

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Based set overlap: dJaccard(,B)=1−|∩B||∪B|d_{Jaccard}(, B) = 1 - \frac{|\cap B|}{|\cup B|} |∩B||\cap B| orthogroups present , |∪B||\cup B| orthogroups present either. Characteristics: - Normalized [0, 1] - Ignores shared absences (double zeros) - Good sparse presence/absence data - Recommended pan-genome analyses

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Originally abundance data, works binary: dBC(,B)=∑|xAi−xBi|∑(xAi+xBi)d_{BC}(, B) = \frac{\sum_i |x_{Ai} - x_{Bi}|}{\sum_i (x_{Ai} + x_{Bi})} Characteristics: - Normalized [0, 1] - Ignores shared absences - Weighs total presence (assemblies orthogroups contribute )

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
code: # Load example data visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") pa <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "pa_binary.rds"))  # Compare dendrograms with different metrics plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard") +   ggplot2::ggtitle("Jaccard Distance")

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: computing distances, assemblies clustered hierarchically. method determines clusters merged.

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Distance clusters = maximum distance pair members. Characteristics: - Produces compact, spherical clusters - Sensitive outliers - Tends find similar-sized clusters

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Distance clusters = average distance pairs members. Characteristics: - Balanced approach - Less sensitive outliers complete - Common phylogenetics

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Minimizes within-cluster variance merge. Characteristics: - Tends produce equal-sized clusters - Good finding natural groupings - aggressive creating distinct clusters
code: # Compare clustering methods plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "complete") plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "average") plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "ward.D2")

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Singletons proteins assigned orthogroup - significant matches proteins assemblies.

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: True uniques: Assembly-specific genes (e.g., horizontally transferred) Divergent homologs: divergent pass similarity thresholds Assembly artifacts: Fragmented genes, contamination Annotation artifacts: Mis-predicted ORFs

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: include singletons: - Analyzing unique gene content - Calculating pan-genome size - Studying accessory genome exclude singletons: - Focusing shared variation - Phylogenetic analysis - Reducing noise artifacts
code: visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") clusters <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "clusters_visual.rds"))  # With singletons (default) pa_with <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, exclude_singletons = FALSE)  # Without singletons pa_without <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, exclude_singletons = TRUE)  cat("With singletons:", nrow(pa_with$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> With singletons: 50 orthogroups cat("Without singletons:", nrow(pa_without$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> Without singletons: 50 orthogroups

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
code: # Total singletons n_singletons(clusters) #> [1] 0  # Per assembly singletons_by_assembly(clusters) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: assembly <chr>, n_singletons <int>  # Access singleton data directly head(get_singletons(clusters)) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: protein_id <chr>, assembly <chr>

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: paneffectR supports multiple clustering tools:

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Comprehensive ortholog inference using gene trees: Advantages: - Gold standard orthology - Handles paralogs correctly - Builds species tree Disadvantages: - Slower DIAMOND RBH - complex output
code: clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "orthofinder")

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Ultra-fast clustering large datasets: Advantages: - Extremely fast - Scales millions proteins - Low memory usage Disadvantages: - Less sensitive DIAMOND - Greedy clustering (order-dependent)
code: clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "mmseqs2")

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Use existing ortholog definitions:
code: # Import OrthoFinder results clusters <- cluster_proteins(   proteins,   method = "precomputed",   precomputed_path = "path/to/Orthogroups.tsv" )  # Import custom CSV (must have: orthogroup_id, assembly, protein_id) clusters <- cluster_proteins(   proteins,   method = "precomputed",   precomputed_path = "my_orthogroups.csv" )

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Presence/absence matrices sparse; consider large datasets DIAMOND -vs-output can large; temporary files cleaned

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: Clustering tools use multiple threads automatically:
code: # Control thread count clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, threads = 8)  # Auto-detect (default) clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins)  # Uses available cores

title: Algorithm Deep Dive
text: defaults chosen good balance speed accuracy typical pan-genome analyses related organisms.

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: vignette demonstrates use paneffectR output omnieff effector prediction pipeline. key advantage ability filter effector prediction scores, focusing analysis high-confidence effector candidates.

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: omnieff runs multiple effector prediction tools combines results: Signal peptide predictors: SignalP 3/4/5/6, Phobius Effector predictors: EffectorP 1/2/3, DeepRedEff Localization: ApoplastP, Localizer Domain annotations: Pfam output includes: FASTA files (*_reformatted.faa): Protein sequences standardized names Score files (*_scored.csv): prediction scores plus combined custom_score Name mapping (*_name_mapping.csv): Links new names original contig names

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Use load_proteins() FASTA score directories: Notice has_scores TRUE assemblies.
code: # Get path to test data (simulates omnieff output structure) testdata_dir <- system.file("testdata", package = "paneffectR")  # Load with scores proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = testdata_dir,   score_dir = testdata_dir,   pattern = "*.faa" ) proteins #> -- protein_collection -- #> 3 assemblies, 300 total proteins #>  #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   assembly_name n_proteins has_scores #>   <chr>              <int> <lgl>      #> 1 assembly1            100 TRUE       #> 2 assembly2            100 TRUE       #> 3 assembly3            100 TRUE

text: filtering, understand score distributions:
code: # Overall distribution plot_scores(proteins) # By assembly plot_scores(proteins, by_assembly = TRUE)

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: custom_score combines multiple predictors. Higher scores indicate stronger effector evidence. Use threshold focus high-confidence candidates:
code: # Show threshold line at score = 5 plot_scores(proteins, threshold = 5.0) # Histogram view plot_scores(proteins, plot_type = "histogram", threshold = 5.0)

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: vignette, ’ll use pre-computed clusters:
code: # Cluster all proteins (requires DIAMOND) clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "diamond_rbh") visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") clusters <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "clusters_visual.rds"))

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Filter high-confidence effectors building matrix: Compare unfiltered:
code: # Load the proteins that match the clusters proteins_visual <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "proteins_visual.rds"))  # Build matrix with score threshold # Only orthogroups containing proteins with score >= 3 are included pa_filtered <- build_pa_matrix(   clusters,   type = "binary",   score_threshold = 3.0,   proteins = proteins_visual ) pa_filtered #> -- pa_matrix (binary) -- #> 36 orthogroups x 6 assemblies #> Sparsity: 34.3% #> Threshold: 3 pa_all <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, type = "binary")  cat("All orthogroups:", nrow(pa_all$matrix), "\n") #> All orthogroups: 50 cat("After score filter:", nrow(pa_filtered$matrix), "\n") #> After score filter: 36

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Instead binary presence/absence, can create matrix actual scores: useful want see just presence/absence, strongly orthogroup predicted effector assembly.
code: # Use maximum score per orthogroup per assembly pa_score <- build_pa_matrix(   clusters,   type = "score",   score_column = "custom_score",   proteins = proteins_visual )  # View scores (0 = absent, otherwise the score value) pa_score$matrix[1:5, ] #>              asm_A    asm_B    asm_C    asm_D    asm_E    asm_F #> OG_acc_01 6.329748       NA       NA       NA 5.634757 4.490995 #> OG_acc_02 4.880568 4.297836       NA 6.800552 6.062126       NA #> OG_acc_03 5.043444 4.251004 6.456519 5.171333 6.114216       NA #> OG_acc_04 5.947353 6.840645 6.917769 4.371568       NA       NA #> OG_acc_05 6.531186       NA 4.749513 5.804187 6.686394 5.975107

code: # Binary heatmap (presence/absence) ht <- plot_heatmap(   pa_filtered,   cluster_rows = TRUE,   cluster_cols = TRUE,   show_row_names = FALSE,   color = c("white", "darkred") ) ComplexHeatmap::draw(ht)

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Present assemblies - likely essential pathogenicity:
code: # Find orthogroups present in all assemblies n_assemblies <- ncol(pa_filtered$matrix) presence_count <- rowSums(pa_filtered$matrix) core_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count == n_assemblies])  cat("Core effector orthogroups:", length(core_og), "\n") #> Core effector orthogroups: 10 cat("Names:", paste(core_og, collapse = ", "), "\n") #> Names: OG_core_01, OG_core_02, OG_core_03, OG_core_04, OG_core_05, OG_core_06, OG_core_07, OG_core_08, OG_core_09, OG_core_10

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Present assemblies:
code: accessory_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count > 1 & presence_count < n_assemblies]) cat("Accessory effector orthogroups:", length(accessory_og), "\n") #> Accessory effector orthogroups: 26

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: Present one assembly - may contribute host specificity:
code: unique_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count == 1]) cat("Unique effector orthogroups:", length(unique_og), "\n") #> Unique effector orthogroups: 0  # Which assemblies have them? unique_assemblies <- apply(pa_filtered$matrix[unique_og, , drop = FALSE], 1, function(x) {   names(x)[x == 1] }) table(unlist(unique_assemblies)) #> < table of extent 0 >

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: paneffectR helps compare proteins across multiple genome assemblies. typical workflow : 1. Load protein sequences FASTA files 2. Cluster proteins orthogroups (groups equivalent proteins) 3. Build presence/absence matrix 4. Visualize results vignette walks step using example data included package.

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR)

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: main entry point load_proteins(), discovers loads FASTA files directory: result protein_collection containing assemblies. can see: many assemblies loaded many proteins Whether effector scores present
code: # Get path to test data included with the package testdata_dir <- system.file("testdata", package = "paneffectR")  # Load all assemblies (FASTAs and scores) proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = testdata_dir,   score_dir = testdata_dir,   pattern = "*.faa" ) proteins #> -- protein_collection -- #> 3 assemblies, 300 total proteins #>  #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   assembly_name n_proteins has_scores #>   <chr>              <int> <lgl>      #> 1 assembly1            100 TRUE       #> 2 assembly2            100 TRUE       #> 3 assembly3            100 TRUE

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: assembly stored protein_set. Access individual assemblies name:
code: # Access one assembly ps <- proteins$assemblies[["assembly1"]] ps #> -- protein_set: assembly1 -- #> 100 proteins #> Scores: present  # The proteins are stored as a tibble head(ps$proteins[, c("protein_id", "sequence", "custom_score", "score_rank")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   protein_id       sequence                              custom_score score_rank #>   <chr>            <chr>                                        <dbl>      <int> #> 1 assembly1_000039 MPFVLNLLVLVAVWYGLVRMAMLLKDDSEIKSFDPF…         4.62         93 #> 2 assembly1_000040 MEVAECTHKLASTTFVKTVEAPALAIMEPLLKRALA…         4.75         64 #> 3 assembly1_000094 MTDKDKPKDDDDCYVKVNTPGGVGDTNSPNKGGLPF…         4.86         27 #> 4 assembly1_000122 MGSSPIFRPFKCKFSMFSKSILIFLLILPLISVILL…         4.81         44 #> 5 assembly1_000164 MLFCVMVGTGCQLLGMALVTLFFAAVGVLAPSNRGK…         4.78         54 #> 6 assembly1_000194 MMGNLAKDIVNGHREKTLALLWKLISCFQLQALVDA…         4.76         59

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: Now group proteins different assemblies orthogroups - sets proteins likely gene/function across assemblies. Note: Clustering requires DIAMOND installed. don’t DIAMOND, can skip step use pre-computed clusters included package visualization examples. vignette, ’ll load pre-computed results:
code: # Cluster using DIAMOND reciprocal best hits clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "diamond_rbh") clusters # Load pre-computed visual test data visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") clusters <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "clusters_visual.rds")) clusters #> -- orthogroup_result (synthetic_visual) -- #> 50 orthogroups

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: orthogroup result contains: orthogroups: proteins belong group singletons: Proteins assigned group (unique one assembly) stats: Summary statistics
code: # See the orthogroup assignments head(clusters$orthogroups) #> # A tibble: 6 × 3 #>   orthogroup_id assembly protein_id #>   <chr>         <chr>    <chr>      #> 1 OG_core_01    asm_A    asm_A_p001 #> 2 OG_core_01    asm_B    asm_B_p002 #> 3 OG_core_01    asm_C    asm_C_p003 #> 4 OG_core_01    asm_D    asm_D_p004 #> 5 OG_core_01    asm_E    asm_E_p005 #> 6 OG_core_01    asm_F    asm_F_p006  # How many singletons? n_singletons(clusters) #> [1] 0  # Singletons by assembly singletons_by_assembly(clusters) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: assembly <chr>, n_singletons <int>

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: paneffectR designed effector analysis, works equally well general pan-genome comparisons protein FASTA files. vignette demonstrates : Compare protein content across genome assemblies Identify core, accessory, unique proteins Visualize pan-genome structure effector scores required.

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: pan-genome represents complete gene content across set related genomes: Core genome: Genes present (nearly ) genomes - essential functions Accessory genome: Genes present genomes - niche adaptation, lifestyle Unique genes: Present one genome - strain-specific features paneffectR helps explore structure presence/absence analysis.

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: pan-genome analysis, need FASTA files: Note: Even though test data scores available, ’re ignoring analysis.
code: # Get path to test data testdata_dir <- system.file("testdata", package = "paneffectR")  # Load FASTAs only (no scores) proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = testdata_dir,   pattern = "*.faa" ) proteins #> -- protein_collection -- #> 3 assemblies, 300 total proteins #>  #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   assembly_name n_proteins has_scores #>   <chr>              <int> <lgl>      #> 1 assembly1            100 FALSE      #> 2 assembly2            100 FALSE      #> 3 assembly3            100 FALSE

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Protein IDs must unique across assemblies. FASTAs generic headers like >protein_001, ’ll need prefix assembly names. paneffectR validates automatically:
code: # This would fail if IDs weren't unique # (our test data already has unique IDs like "assembly1_000001") head(proteins$assemblies[[1]]$proteins$protein_id) #> [1] "assembly1_000039" "assembly1_000040" "assembly1_000094" "assembly1_000122" #> [5] "assembly1_000164" "assembly1_000194"

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Group proteins different assemblies orthogroups: vignette, ’ll use pre-computed clusters:
code: # Cluster using DIAMOND reciprocal best hits clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "diamond_rbh") visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") clusters <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "clusters_visual.rds")) clusters #> -- orthogroup_result (synthetic_visual) -- #> 50 orthogroups

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
code: # Orthogroup statistics clusters$stats #> # A tibble: 1 × 4 #>   n_orthogroups n_singletons n_proteins_clustered n_assemblies #>           <int>        <int>                <int>        <int> #> 1            50            0                  160            6  # How many singletons (unique proteins)? n_singletons(clusters) #> [1] 0  # Singletons per assembly singletons_by_assembly(clusters) #> # A tibble: 0 × 2 #> # ℹ 2 variables: assembly <chr>, n_singletons <int>

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Create binary matrix showing orthogroups assemblies:
code: pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, type = "binary") pa #> -- pa_matrix (binary) -- #> 50 orthogroups x 6 assemblies #> Sparsity: 46.7%  # Include singletons (default) or exclude them pa_no_singletons <- build_pa_matrix(   clusters,   type = "binary",   exclude_singletons = TRUE )  cat("With singletons:", nrow(pa$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> With singletons: 50 orthogroups cat("Without singletons:", nrow(pa_no_singletons$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> Without singletons: 50 orthogroups

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Proteins present assemblies:
code: n_assemblies <- ncol(pa$matrix) presence_count <- rowSums(pa$matrix)  # Core = present in all core_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count == n_assemblies]) cat("Core orthogroups:", length(core_og), "of", length(presence_count), "\n") #> Core orthogroups: 10 of 50 cat("Core percentage:", round(100 * length(core_og) / length(presence_count), 1), "%\n") #> Core percentage: 20 %

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Proteins present assemblies:
code: # Accessory = present in 2 to (n-1) assemblies accessory_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count > 1 & presence_count < n_assemblies]) cat("Accessory orthogroups:", length(accessory_og), "\n") #> Accessory orthogroups: 30 cat("Accessory percentage:", round(100 * length(accessory_og) / length(presence_count), 1), "%\n") #> Accessory percentage: 60 %

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Proteins present one assembly (including singletons):
code: unique_og <- names(presence_count[presence_count == 1]) cat("Unique orthogroups:", length(unique_og), "\n") #> Unique orthogroups: 10 cat("Unique percentage:", round(100 * length(unique_og) / length(presence_count), 1), "%\n") #> Unique percentage: 20 %

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
code: pan_summary <- data.frame(   Category = c("Core", "Accessory", "Unique", "Total"),   Count = c(length(core_og), length(accessory_og), length(unique_og), length(presence_count)),   Percentage = c(     round(100 * length(core_og) / length(presence_count), 1),     round(100 * length(accessory_og) / length(presence_count), 1),     round(100 * length(unique_og) / length(presence_count), 1),     100   ) ) pan_summary #>    Category Count Percentage #> 1      Core    10         20 #> 2 Accessory    30         60 #> 3    Unique    10         20 #> 4     Total    50        100

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: heatmap shows presence (colored) absence (white) patterns:
code: ht <- plot_heatmap(   pa,   cluster_rows = TRUE,   cluster_cols = TRUE,   show_row_names = FALSE,   color = c("white", "steelblue") ) ComplexHeatmap::draw(ht)

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Cluster assemblies shared protein content:  Try different distance metrics:
code: plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard") # Jaccard: good for presence/absence plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard") +   ggplot2::ggtitle("Jaccard Distance")

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Calculate Jaccard similarity pairs:
code: # Simple Jaccard calculation jaccard <- function(a, b) {   intersection <- sum(a == 1 & b == 1)   union <- sum(a == 1 | b == 1)   intersection / union }  # Calculate for all pairs assemblies <- colnames(pa$matrix) n <- length(assemblies) sim_matrix <- matrix(0, n, n, dimnames = list(assemblies, assemblies))  for (i in 1:n) {   for (j in 1:n) {     sim_matrix[i, j] <- jaccard(pa$matrix[, i], pa$matrix[, j])   } }  round(sim_matrix, 2) #>       asm_A asm_B asm_C asm_D asm_E asm_F #> asm_A  1.00  0.49  0.50  0.53  0.44  0.33 #> asm_B  0.49  1.00  0.54  0.57  0.53  0.38 #> asm_C  0.50  0.54  1.00  0.46  0.46  0.43 #> asm_D  0.53  0.57  0.46  1.00  0.49  0.42 #> asm_E  0.44  0.53  0.46  0.49  1.00  0.59 #> asm_F  0.33  0.38  0.43  0.42  0.59  1.00

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
code: # Find most similar pair (excluding diagonal) sim_matrix_upper <- sim_matrix diag(sim_matrix_upper) <- 0 max_idx <- which(sim_matrix_upper == max(sim_matrix_upper), arr.ind = TRUE)[1, ]  cat("Most similar pair:",     assemblies[max_idx[1]], "and", assemblies[max_idx[2]],     "\nJaccard similarity:", round(max(sim_matrix_upper), 3), "\n") #> Most similar pair: asm_F and asm_E  #> Jaccard similarity: 0.588

title: paneffectR
text: Comparative genomics effector proteins across multiple genome assemblies.

title: paneffectR
text: studying plant pathogens, key question : effector proteins shared across isolates, unique? Understanding effector repertoires helps identify core virulence factors, track pathogen evolution, discover candidate avirulence genes. paneffectR solves : Clustering proteins orthogroups - Finding equivalent proteins across assemblies using sequence similarity Building presence/absence matrices - Creating structured data showing proteins exist assemblies Filtering effector scores - Focusing high-confidence effector predictions (using omnieff output) Generating publication-ready visualizations - Heatmaps, UpSet plots, dendrograms designed effector analysis, paneffectR works protein sets general pan-genome comparisons.

title: paneffectR
text: paneffectR requires Bioconductor packages. Install first: install paneffectR GitHub:
code: install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install(c("ComplexHeatmap", "Biostrings")) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("TeamMacLean/paneffectR")

title: paneffectR
text: least one clustering tool must installed. DIAMOND recommended:

title: paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR)  # Load proteins from multiple assemblies proteins <- load_proteins(    fasta_dir = "path/to/fastas/",   score_dir = "path/to/scores/" )  # Cluster into orthogroups clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "diamond_rbh")  # Build presence/absence matrix (filter to high-scoring effectors) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, score_threshold = 5.0)  # Visualize ht <- plot_heatmap(pa) ComplexHeatmap::draw(ht)  plot_upset(pa, min_size = 2)

title: paneffectR
text: Take output omnieff pipeline, find orthologous effectors across assemblies, filter prediction confidence:
code: # Load omnieff output (FASTAs + scores) proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = "omnieff_output/reformatted/",   score_dir = "omnieff_output/scored/" )  # Cluster and build matrix with score threshold clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, score_threshold = 5.0)  # Visualize effector repertoires plot_heatmap(pa) |> ComplexHeatmap::draw()

title: paneffectR
text: Compare protein sets without effector scores:
code: # Load raw FASTAs proteins <- load_proteins(fasta_dir = "my_assemblies/")  # Binary presence/absence analysis clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, type = "binary")  # Identify core vs accessory proteins plot_upset(pa, min_size = 2) plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard")
